Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Multi-Layer Approach Towards Reliable Cognitive Radio Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The development of radio technologies that support efficient and reliable spectrum sharing is an enabler for utilizing the spectrum being made available through the National Broadband Plan. Software defined radios represent a promising technology that supports spectrum sharing as evidenced by the large amount of algorithms and protocols that allow for cognitive radio networks (CRNs) to be deployed. Unfortunately, the economic promise of dynamic spectrum access is easily undermined if cognitive radio users act dishonestly or maliciously, thereby subverting protocols that are founded on the cooperation of users. It is therefore important that mechanisms are developed that ensure the trustworthy operation of CRNs in the presence of potentially malicious or malfunctioning wireless nodes. The objective behind the project's research activities is to develop technological solutions that ensure that cognitive radios operate in trustworthy manner in spite of potential security threats. As a result of this research effort, it is possible for radio spectrum to be more reliably utilized, thereby ensuring that the economic opportunities associated with the radio spectrum are fairly utilized by everyone. The educational impact of the work comes from its multi-disciplinary foundation, broadening student views of wireless system design, and guiding the next generation of wireless engineer to include security and reliability in the design process.

Wireless technologies are an enabler for economic growth in the United States, and cognitive radio networks are an emerging form of wireless system that make spectrum access more available to the broader population. Unfortunately, cognitive radio systems are susceptible to threats that undermine the correct operation of their algorithms and protocols, and thus solutions that support the secure operation of cognitive radio networks are needed. This project ensures the trustworthy operation of cognitive radio networks by: 1) developing algorithms that ensure the correct operation of spectrum sensing procedures upon which spectrum access protocols rely; 2) developing traffic monitoring tools that identify improper communication activity by cognitive radio devices; and 3) developing new forms of interference-resistant communications that ensure that cognitive radio communication continues reliably in the face of interference. The research effort is inter-disciplinary, pulling from statistical tools to network traffic analysis to communications theory to support the secure operation of cognitive radio networks. The algorithms and protocols developed in this project are complemented by a systems prototyping and experimentation effort aimed at guaranteeing that the technologies developed are suitable for deployment in real wireless systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaborative team effort with researchers from Virginia Tech and Rutgers University.  Cognitive radio networks (CRNs) and dynamic spectrum sharing are key technologies to enable more efficient use of limited wireless spectrum, but as such they introduce new security risks to wireless systems.  An overarching objective behind the project is to address many of these security concerns and thereby support the adoption of cognitive radios in future wireless systems. Towards this objective, the team has developed a collection of tools, including algorithms and software, which address three fundamental security challenges: (1) Ensuring the trustworthiness of spectrum sensing, (2) ensuring that cognitive radios operate with proper behavior as a network, and (3) ensuringthat communications survive interference. 

To address the trustworthiness of spectrum sensing, the collaborative effort examined the design of algorithms that optimally scan large swaths of radio spectrum in order to identify unused spectrum. This unused spectrum is valuable to the formation of legitimate communication services, as well as improper (unauthorized) services. The challenge of scanning spectrum to find such opportunities is complicated by the fact that adversaries that attempt to alter the availability of spectrum, or may attempt to affect the accuracy of such data. The team's collaboration resulted in efficient and effective algorithms for identify unused spectrum in the presence of an adversary, as well as algorithms that verify the accuracy of data being shared about radio context. 

To ensure that cognitive radios operate properly, the collaboration has examined the behavior of cognitive radios as a network. The team's analysis started from examining the underlying problem of how adversarial radios might attempt to avoid detection, which led to deeper understanding as to how to locate wireless signals. The team also developed algorithms for analyzing the behavior of cognitive radios in terms of their software configuration. The team has made the novel contribution that analysis of spectrum databases suggests the improper behavior of cognitive radio network protocols and radio behavior. The team has prototyped this tool using Raspberry Pi and USRP radio devices in conjuction and Amazon AWS.

To ensure that communications can survive adversarial interference, the team has explored the use of MIMO and full duplex radio technologies, as well as the underlying tradeoffs that exist at the physical layer when facing adversarial interference. The team's investigation has led to fundamental insights regarding the challenge of maintaining the stability of a communication link when facing interference. This insight can support the design of better communication protocols that maintain a signal's level above a required signal to interference plus noise ratio.  Additionallym, the team's work explored MIMO communications and interference cancellation to ensure that interference is mitigated in a network of cognitive radios. The team has also explored the applicability of full duplex communications to support improved throughput and mitigate interference. The team showed, through a rigorous mathematical formulation, that the multi-hop throughput performance problem can be cast as a formal optimization problem. The team's analysis has provided the fundamental observation that the end-to-end session throughput in a full duplex network can exceed twice that in a conventional half-duplex network. This result highlights an important avenue for cognitive radios to develop for mitigating self-interference and improving overall system communication data rates.
